question: What are the general rules about costs under CPR Part 44?
truth: Part 44 contains the general rules about costs including interpretation and application provisions. Rule 44.1 defines key terms including 'authorised court officer'. Parts 44 to 47 set out the comprehensive costs regime. [General Rules about Costs]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What is the scope of CPR Part 74 regarding enforcement of judgments in different jurisdictions?
truth: Part 74 applies to the enforcement in England and Wales of judgments from different jurisdictions. Section I of this Part sets out the rules for enforcement of foreign judgments. [Enforcement of Judgments in Different Jurisdictions]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does CPR Part 50 say about the application of the Schedules?
truth: Part 50 provides that the Schedules to the CPR set out, with modifications, certain provisions previously contained in other rules. The Schedules preserve important procedural rules from earlier legislation. [Application of the Schedules]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What is the meaning of default judgment under CPR Part 12?
truth: Under Part 12, 'default judgment' means judgment without trial where a defendant has failed to file an acknowledgment of service or a defence. The rules set out when default judgment may be obtained. [Default Judgment]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What is the scope of summary judgment under CPR Part 24?
truth: Part 24 sets out a procedure by which the court may decide a claim or issue without a full trial. Summary judgment may be given where there is no real prospect of success and no other compelling reason for trial. [Summary Judgment]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does CPR Part 31 provide regarding disclosure and inspection of documents?
truth: Part 31 sets out rules about the disclosure and inspection of documents. It defines the scope of disclosure obligations and the procedure for inspection of disclosed documents. [Disclosure and Inspection of Documents]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does CPR Part 33 cover regarding miscellaneous rules about evidence?
truth: Part 33 covers miscellaneous rules about evidence. It defines 'hearsay' as a statement made otherwise than by a person while giving oral evidence. The Part addresses use of hearsay evidence in civil proceedings. [Miscellaneous Rules about Evidence]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does CPR Part 46 cover regarding costs in special cases?
truth: Part 46 addresses costs in special cases, including costs payable by or to particular persons. It covers pre-commencement disclosure and orders for disclosure against non-parties. [Costs special cases]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What is the scope of CPR Part 58 regarding the Commercial Court?
truth: Part 58 applies to claims in the Commercial Court of the King's Bench Division. It sets out the special procedural rules applicable to commercial claims and establishes the jurisdiction of the Commercial Court. [Commercial Court]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does CPR Part 71 provide regarding orders to obtain information from judgment debtors?
truth: Part 71 contains rules about orders to obtain information from judgment debtors. It sets out the procedure for questioning judgment debtors about their means and assets. [Orders to Obtain Information from Judgment Debtors]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does CPR Part 75 cover regarding traffic enforcement?
truth: Part 75 applies to traffic enforcement proceedings. Practice Direction 75 sets out the specific proceedings to which this Part applies and may apply special procedural rules. [CPR Part 75]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What is Practice Direction 3D about costs management?
truth: Practice Direction 3D supplements Part 3 and covers costs management. Section A addresses the production of costs budgets, requiring parties in cases where costs budgeting applies to file and exchange costs budgets. [Costs Management]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 19A cover regarding derivative claims?
truth: Practice Direction 19A supplements CPR Part 19 and covers derivative claims. It sets out the application of this practice direction to claims brought by shareholders on behalf of companies. [Derivative claims]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 31A provide about disclosure and inspection?
truth: Practice Direction 31A supplements CPR Part 31 and provides detailed guidance on disclosure and inspection. It sets out the procedure for standard disclosure and specific disclosure applications. [Disclosure and Inspection]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 31C cover regarding disclosure in competition claims?
truth: Practice Direction 31C addresses disclosure and inspection in relation to competition claims. It provides specific rules for disclosure in cases involving competition law. [Disclosure and inspection in relation to competition claims]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 44 cover as the general rules about costs?
truth: Practice Direction 44 supplements Part 44 and provides detailed guidance on the general rules about costs. Section I covers general provisions applicable to all costs matters. [General Rules about Costs]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 47 cover regarding procedure for detailed assessment?
truth: Practice Direction 47 sets out the procedure for detailed assessment of costs and default provisions. It provides comprehensive guidance on how detailed assessment proceedings should be conducted. [Procedure for Detailed Assessment of Costs and Default Provisions]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 52B provide regarding appeals in the County Court and High Court?
truth: Practice Direction 52B supplements CPR Part 52 and covers appeals in the County Court and High Court. It sets out detailed procedural requirements for appeal proceedings. [Appeals in the county courts and the High Court]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What is the Pilot Scheme under Practice Direction 51ZG3 for QOCS cases?
truth: Practice Direction 51ZG3 establishes a pilot scheme for certain High Court qualified one-way costs shifting (QOCS) cases. It provides special rules for personal injury claims subject to QOCS. [Pilot scheme for certain High Court qualified one-way costs shifting (QOCS) cases]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What does Practice Direction 27B cover regarding claims under the Pre-Action Protocol for Personal Injury?
truth: Practice Direction 27B covers claims under the Pre-Action Protocol for Personal Injury Claims below the small claims limit in road traffic accidents. It provides specific procedural rules for low-value RTA claims. [Practice Direction 27B Injury Claims Below the Small Claims Limit in Road Traffic Accidents – Court Procedure]
category: Civil Procedure Rules and Practice Directions

question: What are the requirements for acknowledgment of service in Commercial Court arbitration claims?
truth: According to Commercial Court Guide section O.5.1, a defendant must file an acknowledgment of service of the arbitration claim form in every case under rule 58.6(1). An adapted version of practice form N210(CC) should be used. [O.  Arbitration, O.5  Acknowledgment of service (p. 126)]

question: What are the time limits for challenging arbitration awards in the Commercial Court?
truth: According to Commercial Court Guide section O.9.1, an application to challenge an award under sections 67 or 68 of the 1996 Act or to appeal under section 69 of the Act must be brought within 28 days. [O. Arbitration, O.9 Time limits (p. 132)]

question: What should the case management bundle contain in the Commercial Court?
truth: According to Commercial Court Guide section D.6.1, before the Case Management Conference, a case management bundle should be prepared by the solicitors for the claimant as required by PD58 §1. [D.  Case Management in the Commercial Court, D.6  Case management bundle (p. 43)]

question: What is the purpose of disclosure in the Commercial Court?
truth: According to Commercial Court Guide section E.1.1, the purpose of disclosure is to assist in achieving the fair disposal and trial of a claim. Regard must be had to the overriding objective and proportionality. [E.  Disclosure, E.1 Generally (p. 60)]

question: What are the requirements for reading lists and trial timetable in the Commercial Court?
truth: According to Commercial Court Guide section J.5.1, unless the Court orders otherwise, a single reading list approved by all advocates must be filed before trial. [J. Trial, J.5 Reading lists, authorities and trial timetable (p. 102)]

question: What steps must be taken before the start of trial in the Commercial Court?
truth: According to Commercial Court Guide section J.3.1, various steps are to be taken by, or by a defined period prior to, the start of the trial. The start of the trial is the first day of the trial window. [J. Trial, J.3 Start of trial (p. 100)]

question: What are the requirements for skeleton arguments in the Commercial Court Appendix?
truth: According to the Commercial Court Guide Appendix, where the Appendix is not complied with, the costs of preparation of the skeleton argument may be disallowed in whole or in part. A skeleton argument must comply with specific formatting requirements. [J. Trial, J.6 Skeleton arguments etc. at trial (p. 103)]

question: What information should be provided in the Commercial Court Case Management Information Sheet?
truth: The Case Management Information Sheet in the Commercial Court requires specific information to be printed in bold characters, including the party filing the information sheet and the name of solicitors. [Appendix 2: Case Management Information Sheet, Progress Monitoring Information Sheet and Pre-Trial Checklist (p. 146)]

question: What are the basic rules for applications in the TCC?
truth: According to TCC Guide section 6.1.1, the basic rules relating to all applications that any party may wish to make are set out in CPR Part 23 and its accompanying Practice Directions. Section 6.1.2 refers to Part 7 of the Practice Direction. [Section 6. Applications after the first CMC, 6.1 Relevant parts of the CPR (p. 44)]

question: How are witness statements prepared in the TCC?
truth: According to TCC Guide section 12.1.1, witness statements should be prepared generally in accordance with CPR Part 22.1 (documents verified by a statement of truth) and CPR Part 32. The general principle is that a witness should set out complete evidence. [Section 12. Witness statements and factual evidence for use at trial, 12.1 Witness statements (p. 81)]

question: What provisions apply to witnesses located outside England and Wales in TCC proceedings?
truth: According to TCC Guide section 12.4.1, if any witness whose witness statement has been served and who is required to give oral evidence is located outside England and Wales, special arrangements may apply. [Section 12. Witness statements and factual evidence for use at trial, 12.1 Witness statements (p. 81)]

question: How are costs assessed after interlocutory hearings in the TCC?
truth: According to TCC Guide section 16.2.1, interlocutory hearings that last one day or less will usually be the subject of a summary assessment of costs in accordance with CPR 44.6. [Section 16. Costs and Costs Management, 16.2 Summary Assessment of Costs (p. 104)]

question: How can TCC judgments be enforced in London?
truth: According to TCC Guide section 17.2.1 (London), a party wishing to make use of any provision of the CPR concerned with the enforcement of judgments and orders made in the TCC in London can use the TCC in London or any other convenient court. [Section 17. Enforcement, 17.2 High Court (p. 108)]

question: When is a reply to the defence necessary in the TCC?
truth: According to the TCC Guide, a reply to the defence is not always necessary. However, where the defendant has raised a positive defence on a particular issue, it may be appropriate to file a reply. [Defence and Reply]

question: What happens when a witness is unwilling to provide a witness statement in TCC proceedings?
truth: According to the TCC Guide, sometimes a witness is unwilling or not permitted or is unavailable to provide a witness statement before the trial. The party seeking to adduce this evidence should apply for appropriate directions. [Section 12. Witness statements and factual evidence for use at trial, 12.1 Witness statements (p. 81)]

question: Which provisions of the Commercial Court Guide apply to Circuit Commercial Court proceedings?
truth: According to Circuit Commercial Court Guide section B3.1, Sub-Section B.4 of the CCG applies to proceedings in the Circuit Commercial Courts save for Paragraph B4.1 which does not apply. Sub-Section B9 of the CCG applies to Part 7 Claims. [The Business and Property Courts The Circuit Commercial Court Guide (pp. 1-2)]

question: What practice should be followed in the Circuit Commercial Courts regarding statements of case?
truth: According to Circuit Commercial Court Guide section C1.1, the practice set out in Section C of the CCG should be followed in the Circuit Commercial Courts except as provided below. Paragraph C2.1 of the CCG applies with equal force. [B.2 Starting a case in a Circuit Commercial Court (pp. 9-10)]

question: What provisions apply following trials in the Circuit Commercial Court?
truth: According to Circuit Commercial Court Guide section J1.1, Section K of the CCG applies following trials in the Circuit Commercial Court save as set out below. [The Business and Property Courts The Circuit Commercial Court Guide (pp. 1-2)]

question: What is Appendix 5 to the Circuit Commercial Court Guide regarding Less Complex Claims?
truth: According to the Circuit Commercial Court Guide, the parties shall comply with Practice Direction 57AD. The case may be treated as a Less Complex Claim within the meaning of Appendix 5 to the CCG. [Appendix B: Specimen Directions, Disclosure (pp. 35-36)]

question: How do the Circuit Commercial Court Users' Committees operate?
truth: According to Circuit Commercial Court Guide section A3.1, each Circuit Commercial Court has a Users' Committee chaired by the Judge in Charge of that Court. Section A3.2 provides that contact details relevant to each Users' Committee are found at the website. [A.3 Circuit Commercial Court Users Committees (pp. 6-7)]

question: Do Pre-Trial Reviews apply in the Circuit Commercial Court?
truth: According to Circuit Commercial Court Guide section D7.1, Sub Section D13 of the CCG does NOT apply to cases in the Circuit Commercial Court. Section D7.2 provides that where a Pre Trial Review (PTR) has been ordered, specific procedures apply. [D.7 Pre-trial checklist (p. 18)]

question: What guidance does the Patents Court provide on bundling for trials?
truth: According to Patents Court Guide section 14.1, bundling for the hearing of applications and trials is of considerable importance and should be approached intelligently. The Direction in Annex E on Standard Trial Bundles provides detailed guidance. [Annex E: Standard trial bundles in the Patents Court (p. 28)]

question: What does Annex E of the Patents Court Guide contain?
truth: Annex E of the Patents Court Guide contains the Direction on Standard Trial Bundles in the Patents Court. It sets out the standard arrangement of bundles so that every document can be easily located. [Annex E: Standard trial bundles in the Patents Court (p. 28)]

question: What is the procedure for intellectual property appeals from the Patents Court?
truth: According to Patents Court Guide section 21.1, the Court of Appeal has issued guidance as to the procedure for all intellectual property appeals, including appeals from the Patents Court. This guidance is reproduced in Annex G to the guide. [21. Appeals to the Court of Appeal (p. 12)]

question: What does Annex G of the Patents Court Guide contain?
truth: Annex G of the Patents Court Guide reproduces the Court of Appeal guidance on intellectual property appeals. It covers procedure for appeals from the Patents Court and other IP matters. [Annex G: Procedure in intellectual property appeals in the Court of Appeal (p. 34)]

question: How does the Patents Court view diversity among advocates?
truth: According to the Patents Court Guide, the Patents Court wishes to promote diversity among those appearing before it. Parties may choose how to use their advocates, but greater use of junior advocates will be encouraged. [5A. Use of junior advocates (p. 2)]

question: How are Patents Court actions allocated to tracks?
truth: According to the Patents Court Guide, actions proceeding in the Patents Court are allocated to the multi-track under Part 63.1(3). Attention is drawn to Part 63.8 and PD63.5 regarding case management. [2. Allocation (p. 2)]

question: What is the draft order annexed to the Patents Court Guide?
truth: According to the Patents Court Guide Annex (A) Commentary, a draft order is annexed covering most normal eventualities. The directions are intended only as a guide and should be adapted as necessary. [Annex B: Specimen order for directions (p. 14)]

question: What are the requirements for time estimates in the Patents Court?
truth: According to Patents Court Guide section 13.1, in providing appropriate time estimates, parties must appreciate the need to give realistic and accurate time estimates and ensure that the time allocated is used efficiently. [Annex D: Practice Statement: Listing of cases for trial in the Patents Court (p. 27)]

question: What does the King's Bench Division Guide say about the 2005 Hague Convention?
truth: According to the King's Bench Division Guide, a list of countries on the Hague Convention website (HCCH Choice of Court Section) have signed up to the 2005 Hague convention on choice of court agreements. Some countries have signed but not ratified. [25. Enforcement in England and Wales of Foreign Judgments and Enforcement abroad]

question: How are hearings before Masters conducted in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to the King's Bench Division Guide section on hearings before Masters, hearings of up to 30 minutes will be listed remotely. For Listing Clerks' contact details, see under 'Contacting the Court'. [9. Hearings (p. 70)]

question: How are deeds enrolled in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 26.1, any deed or document which by virtue of any enactment is required or authorised to be enrolled in the Senior Courts may be enrolled in the Central Office. This commonly arises in cases of change of name. [26. Enrolment of deeds and other documents (p. 207)]

question: What happens when a court strikes out a claim as totally without merit in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 16.3, when a court strikes out a claim form and considers the claim was 'totally without merit' it must record that in the order under CPR 3.4(6). The same applies if an application is dismissed under CPR 23.12 or where an appeal is dismissed. [16. Civil Restraint Orders (p. 139)]

question: What is a litigant in person according to the King's Bench Division Guide?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 2.1, a person who brings or defends legal proceedings without legal representation is known as a 'litigant in person', sometimes shortened to LiP. The rules of practice and procedure apply to litigants in person in the same way as represented parties. [2. Litigants in person (p. 23)]

question: What is the court's power to make orders of its own initiative in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 10.1, the court has power under CPR 3.3 to make an order of its own initiative. Such order may be made after considering representations about the proposed order under rule 3.3(2), after notice of a hearing under rule 3.3(3). [15. Court Orders (p. 134)]

question: How are appeals from Master decisions handled in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to the King's Bench Division Guide, appeals from the decision of a Master are to a High Court Judge and should be made on CE file or filed with the KB Appeals Office if made by a litigant in person not using CE file. [18. Appeals (p. 153)]

question: What is the principle regarding open justice in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 9.2, the starting point is that the administration of justice takes place in public. The public have the right to attend court hearings and the media is able to report proceedings fully. All hearings are normally open. [9. Hearings (p. 70)]

question: What is the Media and Communications List (MAC List) in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 17.1, the Media and Communications List (MAC List) was created in March 2017. It was intended to give new focus to this important specialism within the King's Bench Division and to modernise the listing arrangements. [17. The Media and Communications List (p. 143)]

question: What are the court's powers regarding witnesses in other jurisdictions?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 20.1, the court has no power to compel a witness in another jurisdiction to attend court to give oral evidence or provide documentary evidence. This is subject only to one exception, provided for by Section 36 of the relevant legislation. [Practice Direction 34 A - Depositions and Court Attendance by Witnesses]

question: What is the procedure for enrolling a name change deed for children in the King's Bench Division?
truth: According to the King's Bench Division Guide on enrolling name changes for children, see The Enrolment of Deeds (Change of Name) Regulations 1994, as amended by The Enrolment of Deeds (Change of Name) (Amendment) Regulations 2005. [Annex 12. Guidance for Procedure for Enrolling a Change of Name for Adults]

question: What EU regulations no longer apply for certification and enforcement of judgments after Brexit?
truth: According to King's Bench Division Guide section 25.1, certification, registration, recognition and enforcement of judgments, court settlements, authentic instruments or outgoing protection measures are no longer possible generally under certain Regulations, Conventions and Treaties following Brexit. [25. Enforcement in England and Wales of Foreign Judgments and Enforcement abroad of High Court Judgments (p. 200)]

question: What must be included in the KB Masters Appointment Form?
truth: According to the King's Bench Division Guide, if the KB Masters Appointment Form is not fully completed it will not be shown to the Master and no hearing will be listed. The Master will expect any relevant papers to be provided for the hearing in an agreed hearing bundle. [KB MASTERS APPOINTMENT FORM]
